comment.author: 60142746@N00
comment._content:
LNWR Mail train at Euston c1900


It's 1395 Archimedes, a Webb Dreadnought class divided drive compound. Note the large cylinder-head cover above the buffer beam.

She was built at Crewe in 1886 and scrapped in 1904.

Info from John Whitaker abpr

Handsome engines but prone to slipping. You can't see it in the
picture but these were actually 2-2-2-0 not 2-4-0. The drivers were
uncoupled. If one pair of drivers slipped it lost that one's share of
adhesive weight and the other pair slipped almost immediately.

info from Christopher A Lee abpr

Thanks to the knowledgeable folk at alt.binaries.pictures.rail

comment.author: 56495262@N00
comment._content: I think this is dated 1926, and is probably taken during the General Strike. It looks like it says 5/4/26, which makes it the 4th May 1926, second day of the strike.

comment._content: Coach behind engine has "Manchester" sign  on it. so it's probably Euston station

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: Carlos : Its definitely not the LNWR Loco in your photo - 2-4-0 "Hardwicke" on the turntable, at NRM (National Railway Museum, York, UK). Nice photo though, this loco is very difficult to photo unless the light conditions are exactly right in the Great Hall (old roundhouse). Looking at the running board and splasher designs. The running board has 2 large cut outs, and 2 small ones. The splasher shows the name and you can just make out at least the first letter "A"......; the number 1395 is visible. 'On earlier British locomotives the tops of the wheels usually projected through slots in the running plate and were covered by "splashers" which are analogous to mudguards on a road vehicle.' (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footplate) It is definately a compound (3rd cylinder), and most likely a 2-2-2-0 "Dreadnought", as cited above by Stephen Rees. You can just see the top of the LH cylinder below the running board, ahead of the splasher. (See www.lnwrs.org.uk/PassLocos/PassLoco.php?loco=05 & www.lnwrs.org.uk/PassLocos/PassLocoP.php?loco=05&photo=1 for comparisons ). Possibly there were some renumberings, before scrappings, given this photo shows #1395? Given that the LNWR was amalgamated into the LMS in 1922, ahead of the railway groupings of 1923, there is no signing of any LMS style anywhere in the photo. The coach on the track alongside also looks as it is LNWR livery. The first coach is almost certainly a travelling post office vehicle, with an offset corridor connection, and the rest look similar but with no ducket (lookout). So this is clearly a mail train.
